txt.en: 'Free the other Chayasír taken by the Jangovar. Do not worry over me. I will meet you back at our camp-site.'
Sangemêkh Turáh rescued
Meet Turáh back at the camps
Free the other Chayasír captives ([placeholder]/[placeholder])

#-1:[placeholder]'There #-1:{she[f]|he[m]} is - our daring rescuer. How I wish I could sing this memory into the weave... but, alas! I cannot.\n\n'You look puzzled, [placeholder], and I realize there is much I should explain to you.'
DNT other freed ([placeholder]/[placeholder])
DNT return to the camps
Freed Chayasír captives ([placeholder]/[placeholder])
Find and rescue Sangemêkh Turáh from the Jangovar camp, on the eastern side of the Long Lake.
You should talk to Turáh in the Jangovar camp, on the eastern side of the Long Lake.
You have freed Turáh and the other Chayasír and should meet them back at the refugee camps, in the hills east of Dale.
The Sangemêkh
Rescue Sangemêkh Turáh
DNT talk to the leader

'Terrible news, Enkárvo! Several people from my camp went down to the river, Sangemêkh Turáh among them. There, Jangovar scouts surprised them and took them hostage.

'Do they think we have wealth? Whatever did they hope to gain?

'Oh, [placeholder]. We are able enough to defend ourselves and our own. But we are common folk, and the Jangovar are hardened soldiers. We dare not move against them, not if all of us marched against them.

'But you might. We have heard of your deeds. Would you rescue our Sangemêkh and people from the Jangovar?'
The Sangemêkh Turáh and several other Chayasír were taken hostage by the Jangovar.
DNT free the others ([placeholder]/[placeholder])
Talk to Sangemêkh Turáh
Find and free the other Chayasír captives in the Jangovar camp, on the eastern side of the Long Lake.

'I thank you, stranger. But I am not the only one taken by the Jangovar. Will you find my people and free them, also?\n\n'I will make my way out. Do not fear for me. I think the trouble you are raising in their camp will serve as plenty distraction. I am not helpless or unarmed, thank the earth, and one or two posted guards shall not hinder me, I assure you.'
